Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposer will continue his investigations in multiplicative number theory and the analytic theory of L-functions. The long term goal of this research is to shed light on the sizes and distribution of zeros of L-functions, and to explore the consequences of such results for arithmetical problems. Recently the proposer obtained a ``weak subconvexity" result for a large class of L-functions, and he will investigate generalizations and extensions of that result. Together with Conrey and Iwaniec, the proposer is developing an asymptotic large sieve which promises to give new results on zeros and moments of L-functions in certain families. He will also investigate problems relating to the equidistribution of modular forms. Jointly with Andrew Granville, the proposer has been studying mean values of multiplicative functions over the last ten years, and this activity has found a number of striking applications. The proposer will continue these investigations, and together with Granville is working on a unified treatment of many topics in analytic number theory from this viewpoint.

The proposer works broadly in the area of analytic number theory.
L-functions are of central importance in this area, and encode a great deal of arithmetic information. A key example is the Riemann zeta function which contains much information about the distribution of prime numbers, and an understanding of its zeros is one of the fundamental problems in mathematics.
The proposer's work is motivated by a desire to understand the behavior of such L-functions. The problems in number theory are of intrinsic interest to mathematicians, and pose formidable challenges. Moreover, progress in number theory has had applications in cryptography and theoretical computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a summary of work that I carried out 06/2010 to 05/2016 while supported on NSF grant 1001068.  During this time I made progress on a number of problems in number theory, especially related to prime number theory and the analytic theory of L-functions.   I wrote almost 20 papers during this period, and supervised 8 Ph. D. theses.  I also advised a number of undergraduates, and served as a mentor for several postdoctoral researchers.  I continue to give a number of talks at conferences and lecture series, within the US and internationally.  

The highlights of my research during this period include a number of projects with my former student Radziwill, leading most notably to our work resolving one half of a conjecture of Keating and Snaith which was published in Inventiones.  I also completed a series of papers with Conrey and Iwaniec, developing a flexible tool known as the asymptotic large sieve.   One consequence of this work shows that a large proportion of the zeros of Dirichlet L-functions lie on the critical line, as predicted by the Riemann Hypothesis.   A third highlight of my work in this period is the explanation of curious patterns in the distribution of consecutive primes.  This was carried out with Robert Lemke Oliver, an NSF postdoctoral fellow whom I mentored.  Our work (which appeared in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences) received a lot of media attention, and I have used it as a vehicle in communicating mathematical research to a broad audience (for example, to high school students, and to scientifically interested people outside academia).  

Besides these highlights, I continued my long term work with Andrew Granville on multiplicative functions; we completed several projects that had been in progress, and worked further towards our research monograph on the subject.  I formed new collaborations with Bellaiche (mixing analytic methods with his expertise on Galois representations to establish results on non-vanishing of modular form coefficients mod p), Harper, Rodgers, among others.
